Description: Lower body fragment of Attic black-figured pottery closed vase, amphora or hydria? Part of komos scene; remaining are the legs of a male dancing to right; glazed black below. No added colour.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Venit: 'Connected with the Komast Group. The fat thighs and lack of incision for the ankle bone of the dancer connect this fragment with other works by painters in the Komast Group. Compare, for example, Oxford G 131.31 (CVA Great Britain 9: pl.2 fig.1; ABV 36,2 [foot]).' Members of the Komast group rarely produced large closed vases. Published also in JARCE 21 (1984) 148 fig.11.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 71, no. 234 pl. 52)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p. 148, fig. 11)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0882)
